children.subject: AIs are treated separately from paid course staff in general (since you're not an official paid employee of the department), however I would strongly advise you check with the course directly as it may create a conflict of interest.
Not sure if it's allowed, but even if no one explicitly say it's not, I would strongly recommend you don't do it, especially if you have access to staff solutions for any assignments as an AI.

history.content:
<md>You should ask John DeNero about the ethics of doing this. He's the one who monitors the private tutor list, looking to see who is receiving payment as a UGSI, AI or reader and is also putting themselves on the private tutor list. My feeling would be that if you are working for a class, you should be working for the benefit of all of the students equally and not especially on behalf of one particular student who is paying you. This would create a conflict of interest for you.

Update [from John DeNero]: First of all, thanks for asking! I would describe this combination (AI + private tutor) as a bad idea that isn't forbidden. Academic Intern positions aren't paid course staff positions and primarily exist for the interns to learn about teaching. Therefore, it's not the department's place to put restrictions on your external employment or time. That said, the goal of an internships is to integrate you into the course staff and give you that experience. As a result, I'd recommend that you avoid anything that would be viewed as a conflict of interest if one were in an official course staff position (reader, tutor, or GSI). If that's not clear enough, please use your judgment: would students in the course view a private tutor relationship with an AI as an unfair advantage? I think they could, so that's why I'd recommend against it.</md>

You should ask John DeNero about the ethics of doing this. He's the one who monitors the private tutor list, looking to see who is receiving payment as a UGSI, AI or reader and is also putting themselves on the private tutor list. My feeling would be that if you are working for a class, you should be working for the benefit of all of the students equally and not especially on behalf of one particular student who is paying you. This would create a conflict of interest for you.

children.subject: <md>Certainly we won't hold this against you.</md>

Update: I'm actually not doing any paid tutoring either now or for the rest of summer semester, since the student offering the opportunity didn't want it anymore. So hopefully no bad mark on my AI record, I hope!

history.content:
Update: I'm actually not doing any paid tutoring either now or for the rest of summer semester, since the student offering the opportunity didn't want it anymore. So hopefully no bad mark on my AI record, I hope!

I'm an Academic Intern for a lower division CS class this summer. A student has offered to hire me as a private tutor for the same class I'm AIing, for hourly pay. I don't intend to list myself on the Private Tutor List google sheets, though. I can handle the time commitment. Is this permissible?

I see on the Private Tutor List for Summer 2021 piazza post that "GSI/tutors/readers" on a course's staff aren't allowed to offer private tutoring for that same class. But does that extend to Academic Interns?
history.subject: Private tutoring and being AI for same class simultaneously
